docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor gets very tired of this kind of thing: sending a child with asthma home to an apartment full of roaches and mold; telling the parents of an anemic toddler to buy more and healthier food when they clearly do not have a cent; seeing babies who live in unheated apartments come in again and again with lung ailments. At Boston Medical Center, the hospital that treats more poor people than any other in Massachusetts, pediatricians got so tired of it that they decided to try a radical solution: getting their own lawyers.

headline.main: Boston Medical Center Turns to Lawyers for a Cure

docs.abstract: Boston Medical Center, which treats more poor people than any other Massachusetts hospital, has own legal staff to fight legal and administrative battles to get poor children nutrition and housing they need to prevent and treat disease; program goes far beyond social work hospitals normally provide; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush warmly endorsed a new bill defining patients' rights today, but the legislation was immediately attacked, for different reasons, by Democrats and Republicans, health insurance companies and employers. The chief sponsor of the bill, Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, said he had drafted the legislation to satisfy criteria set forth by Mr. Bush in February.

headline.main: New Bill on Patients' Rights Is Both Hailed and Criticized

docs.abstract: Pres Bush endorses Sen Bill Frist bill defining patients' rights; Democrats and Republicans, health insurance companies and employers attack bill for different reasons; bill would give patients limited new right to sue HMO's in federal court if health plans refuse to abide by decisions of independent medical reviewers; would bar punitive damages and limit other damage claims by injured patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from Massachusetts officials concerning Medicaid reimbursement for the company's products, becoming the latest of several large drug makers to be investigated for pricing practices. Eli Lilly, which is based in Indianapolis, said in its quarterly financial filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had received a subpoena from the Massachusetts attorney general's office in March.

headline.main: Eli Lilly Gets Subpoena About Medicaid Pricing

docs.abstract: Eli Lilly & Co receives subpoena from Massachusetts officials concerning Medicaid reimbursement for company's products (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Allergy sufferers who hope that Claritin will soon be available over the counter may well be waiting for many months, if not years. On Friday, a committee of experts advised the Food and Drug Administration that Claritin and two other popular allergy drugs, Allegra and Zyrtec, were safe enough to be made available without a prescription.

headline.main: Delays Possible for Over-the-Counter Allergy Drugs

docs.abstract: It is not clear whether Food and Drug Administration has authority to force allergy drug manufacturers, Schering-Plough, Aventis and Pfizer Inc, to make products available over the counter; drug companies are almost certain to fight back in court, even if government does order change; advisory committee review of status of drugs was requested by Wellpoint Health Networks, insurance company; typically, pharmaceutical companies are ones that ask for permission to sell their drugs without prescription (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing huge deficits, New York City hospital officials have sought the state's permission to shut down more than two dozen school-based and neighborhood health clinics where poor children get basic medical care, from immunizations to treatment for asthma. Officials with the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the clinics, said the closings were necessary because of changes in health care financing that have saddled the agency with a $300 million budget deficit this year. The number of uninsured patients has also ballooned by 30 percent in the last four years alone, agency officials said.

headline.main: Health Agency Seeks to Close 27 Clinics

docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article yesterday about efforts to head off reductions in Medicare spending misspelled the surname of the Republican senator from Texas who introduced a bill that would reverse them. She is Kay Bailey Hutchison, not Hutchinson.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey companies paid the highest premiums in the nation for individual employee health insurance plans, and New York companies paid the most for family plans, according to a Rutgers University study of 1998 data from 40 states for which figures were available. Connecticut businesses paid the second-highest premiums in both categories, according to the study, which will be discussed at a symposium today at the Princeton Marriott. New Jersey companies paid an average of $2,541 per year for individual policies, and $6,332 per year for family plans, the third-highest average. New York companies paid an average of $2,372 for individual plans, the 12th-highest average, but $6,453 for family plans. Connecticut businesses paid an average of $2,485 for individual plans and $6,380 for family plans. The national averages were $2,174 and $5,590. Kimberly Fox, a policy analyst at the Rutgers Center for State Health Policy who led the study, said probable reasons for the high premiums included higher costs generally in the Northeast and longer hospital stays. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jason Esters, who is finishing a doctorate in English at Temple University here, always considered himself a scholar. But lately he feels more like a laborer, and one with rather oppressive working conditions. These days, he says, conversations between graduate students have been less about Chaucer and Nietzsche and more about their burdens as teaching assistants -- grading papers for 40 hours a week and having trouble affording health insurance.

headline.main: Graduate Students Push For Union Membership

docs.abstract: After decade of prosperity for American universities, there is growing unrest on campuses as graduate students and adjunct professors focus increasingly on bread-and-butter issues and turn for help to unlikely place, namely, labor unions; recent unionization drives at University of Pennsylvania, Columbia, Brandeis and Brown University noted; developments follow success by New York University's 1,400 graduate teaching and research assistants in becoming first students at private university to gain union recognition by winning approval to join United Automobile Workers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In May 1987, Dan Shapiro, then a 20-year-old junior at Vassar College, discovered he had Hodgkin's disease. After seven months of treatment with four chemotherapy drugs and radiation, he seemed healthy again. In 1988, in his first year of graduate school in clinical psychology, he counseled a young girl named Jodi who was not doing well after a bone marrow transplant for the same cancer and who soon died. Six months later, he learned that his own cancer had returned and that his only hope was a bone marrow transplant. His survival chances were 40 percent. Sixteen months after the transplant, in July 1991, he had a second relapse, and few options remained.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: Dan Shapiro; A Doctor's Story of Hope, Humor and Deadly Cancer

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Dan Shapiro, clinical psychologist and former cancer patient in Tucson, Ariz, who applies what he has learned to help patients get what they need from doctors, and to help doctors practice more humane and integrated form of medicine; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Second Pardon Front First there were those who said that DENISE RICH did too much to help her former husband, Marc, get a pardon. Now there are those who say she did too little to help a former beau, DR. NIELS LAUERSEN, get one, too.
docs.abstract: Dr Niels Lauerson, gynecologist convicted of fraudulently billing insurance companies for patients' expensive fertility treatments, failed to receive pardon from President Clinton despite relationship with Denise Rich; actor Peter Cincotta, 17, asks actress Jennifer Love Hewitt to his senior prom; celebrities attending Felix Trinidad-William Joppy boxing match at Madison Square Garden noted; scene at screening of movie Swordfish described; photo (M)
